title: Fairytales for Wilde Girls
author: Allyse Near
review:
html:

Described on the back as “bubblegum gothic”, the prose sings to you — vicious, bloody and glittery.

Even after reading I felt like the world had changed.

title: Sufficient Grace
author: Amy Espeseth
review: Deceptively simple tale that sucks you in.

title: Seahearts
author: Margo Lanagan
review: Well, basically anything by Margo Lanagan. Her work is part dream and part nightmare but all of it is amazing. She is one of Australia’s greatest writers.

title: A Certain Slant of Light
author: Laura Whitcomb
review: A dreamlike take on ghost stories and possession. I never knew books could be like this.

title: Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children
author: Ransom Riggs
review: I was working in a café when a customer lent me this book; that’s how badly she wanted me to read it and how much she knew I would love it. Don’t worry I gave it back to her sans dog ears and jam and butter smears.

title: We have always lived in the Castle
author: Shirley Jackson
review:
html:

Another book I wrote about in my thesis. This book doesn’t seem to have the renown as Jackson’s The Lottery, or The Haunting of Hill House does, but I think it’s her best.

There’s something NQR about the narrator Mary Katherine. She’ll draw you into her madness and have you nodding along with her and her dark machinations.

title: Cuckoo Song
author: Frances Hardinge
review: Why are there not more stories from a Changeling’s point of view?

title: The Sandman
author: Neil Gaiman
review: Neil Gaiman, do I really need to say why?

title: Black Spring
author: Alison Croggon
review:
html:

I saw the cover of this book in my local Dymocks and had to pick it up. It’s a fantastic reimagining of Wuthering Heights. I’ve written a guest post about it on The Book Wars.

The character of Lina fascinates me, as much as I find her abhorrent and fearful. I loved this book so much that I wrote about it in my thesis!

title: The Night Circus
author: Erin Morgenstern
review: If you didn’t like this book I am not sure that we can be a friend; that’s how strongly I feel about it. Once you’ve been drawn into the world, it stays with you long after you’ve finished reading it.

title: Ophelia and the Marvellous Boy
author: Karen Foxlee
review: An unusual retelling of the Snow Queen.

title: Undine
author: Penni Russon
review:
html:

Dreamy, makes Tasmania a mystical island worthy of Shakespeare’s Prospero!

I’ve met Penni; she let me touch her on the arm. Also she was my tutor for a couple of subjects, and read some early drafts of Cloud Collectors. She’s an amazing writer and a great teacher.

title: Daughter of Smoke and Bone
author: Laini Taylor
review: Funny, dark, self-aware. Epic world building.

title: American Gods
author: Neil Gaiman
review: I suspect this book is closer to reality than even Mr Gaiman believes.

title: A Monster Calls
author: Patrick Ness
review:
html:

Heartbreaking, and an escape from the real world as well as embracing it. More books need such beautiful illustrations.

I don’t think I’ve ever physically cried while reading a book, except for A Monster Calls.

title: This is Shyness
author: Leanne Hall
review: Such a crazy new world that feels so familiar.

title: Love
author: Angela Carter
review: So much to love in such a tiny book. Carter is one of my favourite writers. I have to credit her with reviving my love of gothic.
